reviewText: This series is loaded with suspense, an excellent story line, plenty of mystery, and surprizing plots.  Yes, the music may be a bit lame occasionally and the speech fast enough to have to stop and play back the subtitles, but, it is outstanding!

reviewText: I was so excited to discover that "La Piovra" was available in NTSC, because I began watching the series on television in Rome in the 1980s (and saw the final series of the epic in the 90s). The English "Octopus" does not do the title of this film justice, because a "piovra" is not just any old octopus, or "polpo", but a gigantic mythical creature, capable of engulfing large ships. Its tentacles are both far-reaching and all-enveloping. And in 1984, when "La Piovra" was aired on RAI-TV, the scenario of the film was considered especially daring since, despite the disclaimer that "any resemblance to events or persons living or dead is purely coincidental", the incidents and personages of the series reflected the headlines and news stories of the day: kidnappings of young girls, murders of investigating judges, bombings, payoffs, secret societies; crooked bankers, prelates, and politicians with links to organised crime.Thanks to excellent writing and performances, as well as a top-notch musical score, written and conducted by Ennio Morricone, "La Piovra" has retained all of its pristine excitement; it's hero, Commissario Cattani is portrayed by a handsome brooding Michele Placido, and the villain I absolutely loved to hate, Avvocato Terrasini, is played with an oily suavity by Franois Perrier. The plot is so riveting and complex that one will overlook the deterioration of the colour and the print (but, perhaps, it will be better to watch this DVD on your computer, rather than on a large television screen which tends to distort the picture).The subtitles (in excellent English) are able to be switched on or off, as the viewer wishes. And, while I lament the deterioration of the cinematography (since the picture takes us to Geneva, Palermo, and Rome), I feel we are lucky to have this top-notch series in any form whatsoever.
summary: Five Star Production; Worth the Deterioration of the Image!

reviewText: I anticipated an incredible series but from the start found it over-acted, over-dramatic and extremely repetitively boring !! The initial character of a police inspector taking on the Mafia was unrealistic and reflected a "glamorous" martyr with whom every woman he met falling madly in love with him and he with almost every woman !! There is lots of sobbing and gloom interspersed with violent and/or secret confrontations with the Mafia's "wheeling and dealing," corrupt government officials or police officers. Needless to say all the honest police officers do not last long !! Overall, just too much interpretation of not much in the way of a perennial story line - even the inspector's death was absolutely "over the top," with a self-sacrificial ending !! Gave up on the series at about Set 4 and traded them in !! Could not give this series anything but two stars !!
summary: Very disappointing - could not stick with it !!

reviewText: Spoiler warning! This review of Octopus Season 2 reveals key plot details from Season 1.Moving into Season 2, this series remains as compelling as before.  While Season 1 "set the scene", so to speak, in Season 2 the storyline becomes considerably more complex, as more characters and nuances are explored and the atmosphere becomes  darker and more sinister.One of the great things about The Octopus is that, while being intelligent drama of the highest quality, it's so easy to watch.  The episodes are well paced, and the viewer will be engaged within the first few minutes of each episode - there are no long lead-in times before things become interesting and the story is never laboured or a drag.Season 2 opens in Geneva, Switzerland, where Corrado Cattani's daughter Paola is in a psychiatric institution being treated for depression and trauma as a consequence of her abduction and rape by the Mafia at the end of Season 1.  Her parents are with her in Geneva to help her get better. Corrado, now 38 years old, has had enough of life as a policeman in Sicily, with all its intrigues and violence, and just wants to lead a quiet life caring for Paola.In Geneva, a stranger by the name of Ettore Ferretti insists on meeting with Corrado.  It turns out he's the deputy of Sebastiano Cannito, Corrado's mentor from his police academy days and now a top government official in Rome.  Ferretti says he's investigating his boss Cannito's links with the Mafia and with the mysterious Professor Laudeo, who heads the secret political organisation "Itala".  Ferretti says the two are behind murky business deals, arms trafficking and suspicious political appointments.  He wonders whether they're only interested in private financial gain, or whether they have a broader, more sinister purpose - to overthrow Italy's political institutions.Ferretti asks Corrado to help with the investigation, as he believes Corrado to be loyal, honest, intelligent and tenacious. In return, Ferretti offers to reinstate Corrado to his old position and have his misconduct case closed.Given Ferretti is Cannito's deputy, Corrado sees all this as an internal rivalry or power struggle and declines Ferretti's request for help.  Corrado says his first priority is his daughter's welfare and he's just not interested. Will Corrado change his mind?Meanwhile, back in Sicily, Corrado is under investigation by Judge Bordonaro for giving into blackmail and acting contrary to his duty as a public official, due to his televised public admission of abuse of power, forgery and concealing evidence back in Season 1.  Corrado however maintains his conduct was justified because he was under duress as a result of his daughter's abduction by the Mafia.  Pending the outcome of the investigation, Corrado has been suspended from duty.Judge Bordonaro is also investigating Paola's abduction.  He's questioning a man named Manrocco, who's believed to have kept Paola imprisoned in his house in return for money paid by the Mafia.  Other Mafia figures we're familiar with from Season 1 - Terrasini, Ravenusa, Countess Olga Camastra - are also being questioned.Apparently out of the blue, Bordonaro telephones Cannito in Rome, saying he needs to see Cannito urgently on a confidential matter.  Cannito is taken aback, but agrees to see Bordonaro.  Why does Bordonaro insist on meeting Cannito, given the two don't know each other? What did Bordonaro's interviews with Mafia figures reveal about Cannito?Bordonaro then calls Corrado in Switzerland to tell him about the upcoming meeting with Cannito in Rome.  Corrado is aghast at the meeting, and warns Bordonaro in the strongest terms not to meet Cannito before seeing Corrado first.  Bordonaro agrees to meet Corrado in Rome, and cancels the appointment with Cannito.  Why? What vital information does Corrado need to give Bordonaro about Cannito?These are some of the intriguing storylines explored in Season 2. The focus shifts somewhat from the localised organised crime of the Sicilian Mafia to the broader power the Mafia holds within Rome's political elite, such as Cannito.  What also emerges from Season 2 is that when it comes to the Mafia it isn't always a case of good versus bad, Mafia against law enforcement; the reality is far more nuanced, and sometimes the only long-term hope of combating the Mafia effectively is to deal with them, even accept their help.As with Season 1, the performances and script remain superb.  Corrado Cattani's personality changes in Season 2, becoming darker, more cynical and driven by revenge, and this is portrayed very well by Placido.  One thing I also liked in Season 2 is how good the music/sound effects are - they convey the overall suspense and mystery of the series very well.To wrap up, if you enjoyed Season 1, you must watch this second season, and the new intrigues described above will honestly keep you glued to your TVs.

reviewText: On the surface, THE OCTOPUS is simply a gangbusting tale, the story of the no-holds-barred war between a handful of dedicated cops and the sprawling, many-tentacled Mafia of Sicily. Dig deeper, however, and you soon discover that this show not only has all the elements of great drama - well-developed characters, complex sub-plots, star-crossed romances, brutal volence, and moral confusion par excellance - it is also a fascinating study of the way the Mafia has entrenched itself into the very highest levels of political and business life: not only in Sicily but in mainland Italy as well. When crusading cop Corrado Cattani first arrived in Sicily at the opening of Series 1, he thought himself merely opposing the local crime syndicate. He had no idea that the very men who sent him to Sicily were part of that syndicate, and that there was nothing whatsoever "local" about it. It's not for nothing the Italians call the Mafia "the octopus", because its tentacles are everywhere.Series 2 of THE OCTOPUS picks up where Series 1 left off. After going head-to-head with the Mafia in its backyard, a battered Corrado Cattani has returned to Rome with his family to lick his emotional wounds, patch up his broken marriage to wife Else, and oversee the recovery of his daughter Paola. He thinks his mob-busting days are over, but events soon conspire to draw him back into combat with "la piovra." A crusading judge named Bardonero has obtained secret information from Cattani's old deputy, Altero, that may bring down many of the mob's power-players back in Sicily. After an outburst of brutal violence reminds Cattani just what he left behind in Sicily, he finds himself pressured by an upright government official, Colonel Feretti, to exploit his position as a police official to get close to those in the power structure supportive of the Mafia. Cattani refuses, but after a grisly series of mob-inspired tragedies completely wreck his life and ruin his reputation, he returns to the fight with a vengeance. As the saying goes, however, this time it's personal, and Cattani is no longer interested in the small-fry Mafia soldiers he warred with before, but in the men and women who give them orders - the lawyer Terrasini, the sultry Countess Olga, the smoothly villainous businessman Laudeo, and even his old friend and mentor, government official Cannito. Obsessed with revenge, the former moralist manipulates and exploits everyone around him, using the appearance of corruption to gain the trust of his former enemies. And as it turnes out, "the Octopus" has problems enough already. When American Mafiosi Frank Carrisi shows up in Sicily looking to set up shop, his presence and money drive a wedge between the Mafia, run by Terrassini and financed by Olga, and "Itala", the mainland political syndicate run by the Romans, Laudeo and Cannito. A dirty war breaks out between the two factions, and Cattani decides to exploit it. This decision leads to chaos which shakes the foundations of the mob, the Italian government, and Corrado Cattani himself.THE OCTOPUS is the very definition of addictive television.  The performances by Michele Placido (Cattani), Francois Perier (Terrasini), Renato Cachetto (Bardonero), Michele Abruzzo (Bardonero's replacement, the oily Scardona), and Luciano de Ambros (the morally conflicted Cannito) are all outstanding. American actor Martin Basalm is terrifying as the semi-Satanic Sicilian-American Carrisi, whose refusal to be squeezed by Itala triggers the war between the two mobs. Nicole Jamet is also excellent as Cattani's confused and long-suffering wife Else, whose love for her husband somehow only makes their relationship the more tragic. It's true that this series takes longer to get going than the previous one, and that the drama occasionally slips into melodrama, but it's equally true that when this show decides to crank up tension, discomfort, or anxiety, it does so at the flip of the switch. We care about these characters, and we care what happens to them - which, given the pitiless, "no one is safe" style of the story, makes for even greater suspense.
Title: N/A
